data.question: 1. What is Object-Oriented Programming (OOP)?
data.answer: Answer: ● OOP is a programming paradigm that organizes software around objects, which contain data (fields/properties) and behavior (methods/functions). ● Helps model real-world entities and their interactions.

data.question: 2. What are the four pillars of OOP?
data.answer: Answer: 1. Encapsulation – Hiding internal details of objects and exposing only necessary functionality. 2. Abstraction – Hiding implementation details and showing only essential features. 3. Inheritance – Allowing a class to inherit properties and methods from another class. 4. Polymorphism – Allowing objects to take multiple forms.

data.question: 3. Why is OOP preferred over procedural programming?
data.answer: Answer: ● Promotes code reusability through classes and objects. ● Easier to maintain and extend large applications. ● Better organization through modular design. ● Supports complex real-world modeling.

data.question: 4. How does OOP help in software development?
data.answer: Answer: ● Encourages modular code → easier to maintain and test. ● Reduces code duplication through inheritance and composition. ● Improves code organization and readability. ● Enables better collaboration through clear interfaces.

data.question: 5. What is a class in OOP?
data.answer: Answer: ● A class is a blueprint or template for creating objects. ● It defines the properties (fields) and behaviors (methods) that objects of that class will have. ● Example: 'Car' class defines properties like color, model and methods like Start(), Stop().

data.question: 6. What is an object?
data.answer: Answer: ● An instance of a class with actual values. ● Represents a real-world entity in memory. ● Example: A specific car object with color='Red', model='SUV'.

data.question: 7. What is the difference between a class and an object?
data.answer:
Answer: 
Feature        Class                    Object
Definition     Blueprint/Template       Instance of class
Memory         No memory allocated      Memory allocated when created
Usage          Defines structure        Contains actual data
Example        Car class                MyCar object with specific values

data.question: 8. What is a constructor?
data.answer: Answer: ● A special method that is called automatically when an object is created. ● Used to initialize the object's fields. ● Has the same name as the class and no return type.

data.question: 9. What is a destructor?
data.answer: Answer: ● A method called automatically when an object is destroyed. ● Used to release resources before the object is removed from memory. ● In C#, called Finalize() and managed by garbage collector.

data.question: 10. What are instance vs static members in a class?
data.answer: Answer: ● Instance members → Belong to each object, require object to access. ● Static members → Belong to the class itself, shared by all objects. ● Example: Instance - each car has its own speed; Static - total number of cars created.

data.question: 11. What is encapsulation?
data.answer: Answer: ● The practice of hiding internal details of a class and exposing only necessary functionality through access modifiers and properties. ● Example: private int speed; public int Speed { get; set; }

data.question: 12. How does encapsulation help in security?
data.answer: Answer: ● By making fields private, external code cannot directly modify sensitive data. ● Access is controlled via methods or properties, enforcing validation rules. ● Prevents invalid state changes and maintains data integrity.

data.question: 13. How is encapsulation implemented in C#?
data.answer: Answer: ● Use private fields to store data. ● Expose controlled access via public properties or methods. ● Use getters and setters with validation logic.

data.question: 14. What are access modifiers?
data.answer: Answer: ● Keywords that define visibility of class members. ● Common C# modifiers: public, private, protected, internal, protected internal.

data.question: 15. What is the use of internal, protected, and protected internal?
data.answer: Answer: ● Internal → Accessible only within the same assembly. ● Protected → Accessible in the class and derived classes. ● Protected Internal → Accessible in derived classes OR within same assembly.

data.question: 16. What is the use of properties in encapsulation?
data.answer: Answer: ● Properties provide controlled access to private fields. ● Enable validation, read-only/write-only access, and future flexibility. ● Allow data binding and additional logic in getters/setters.

data.question: 17. What is abstraction?
data.answer: Answer: ● Hiding implementation details and showing only the essential features of an object. ● Achieved using abstract classes and interfaces. ● Example: Car interface with Start() method hides how engine starts.

data.question: 18. Why is abstraction important?
data.answer: Answer: ● Simplifies complex systems by exposing only relevant functionality. ● Enhances maintainability, readability, and reusability of code. ● Reduces complexity and improves code organization.

data.question: 19. How do you implement abstraction in C#?
data.answer: Answer: ● Using abstract classes or interfaces. ● Abstract classes can have abstract and non-abstract methods. ● Interfaces define contracts that implementing classes must follow.

data.question: 20. How does abstraction reduce complexity?
data.answer: Answer: ● Hides implementation details, allowing developers to work at higher level of abstraction. ● Provides clear boundaries between components. ● Makes code easier to understand and modify.

data.question: 21. What is inheritance?
data.answer: Answer: ● A mechanism where a class (child) inherits properties and methods from another class (parent). ● Promotes code reusability and establishes 'is-a' relationships. ● Example: Car class inherits from Vehicle class.

data.question: 22. What is the base class and derived class?
data.answer: Answer: ● Base Class (Parent) → Class whose members are inherited. ● Derived Class (Child) → Class that inherits from base class. ● Example: class Vehicle (base) → class Car : Vehicle (derived)

data.question: 23. How is inheritance implemented in C#?
data.answer: Answer: ● Using the colon (:) symbol. ● Derived class can access public/protected members of the base class. ● Example: class Car : Vehicle

data.question: 24. What is the : base() keyword used for?
data.answer: Answer: ● Calls the constructor of the base class from a derived class. ● Ensures base class initialization before derived class constructor runs. ● Can pass parameters to base constructor.

data.question: 25. Can you inherit multiple classes in C#?
data.answer: Answer: ● No, C# does not support multiple class inheritance. ● A class can inherit from only one base class. ● Use interfaces for multiple inheritance-like behavior.

data.question: 26. What is the difference between inheritance and composition?
data.answer:
Answer: 
Feature        Inheritance          Composition
Relationship    "is-a"               "has-a"
Flexibility     Less flexible        More flexible
Coupling        Tight coupling       Loose coupling
Reusability     White-box reuse      Black-box reuse

data.question: 27. What is polymorphism?
data.answer: Answer: ● Ability of an object to take multiple forms. ● Types: Compile-time (method overloading) and Runtime (method overriding). ● Example: Animal class with Speak() method, Dog and Cat override it differently.

data.question: 28. What is compile-time polymorphism?
data.answer: Answer: ● Also called static polymorphism. ● Achieved through method overloading and operator overloading. ● Resolution happens at compile time.

data.question: 29. What is runtime polymorphism?
data.answer: Answer: ● Also called dynamic polymorphism. ● Resolved at runtime using method overriding. ● Base class reference can point to derived class objects.

data.question: 30. What is method overloading?
data.answer: Answer: ● Same method name with different parameters in the same class. ● Enables compile-time polymorphism. ● Different signatures based on parameter types/count.

data.question: 31. What is method overriding?
data.answer: Answer: ● Derived class provides a new implementation for a virtual method in base class. ● Enables runtime polymorphism. ● Requires virtual keyword in base, override in derived.

data.question: 32. What is the difference between overriding and overloading?
data.answer:
Answer: 
Feature        Overloading          Overriding
Compile/Runtime Compile-time          Runtime
Parameters      Different            Same
Inheritance     Same class           Different classes
Keyword         None                 override

data.question: 33. What is an interface?
data.answer: Answer: ● An interface is a contract that defines method signatures, properties, events, or indexers without providing implementation. ● Classes or structs that implement the interface must provide the implementation.

data.question: 34. How do you define an interface in C#?
data.answer: Answer: ● Use interface keyword. ● Example: public interface IDriveable { void Drive(); int Speed { get; set; } }

data.question: 35. What is the syntax to implement an interface?
data.answer: Answer: ● Use the colon (:) symbol and implement all members. ● Example: class Car : IDriveable { public void Drive() { } public int Speed { get; set; } }

data.question: 36. Can a class implement multiple interfaces?
data.answer: Answer: ● Yes, a class can implement multiple interfaces, solving multiple inheritance issues. ● Example: class FlyingCar : IDriveable, IFlyable

data.question: 37. What is an abstract class?
data.answer: Answer: ● An abstract class is a class that cannot be instantiated directly. ● Can contain abstract methods (without implementation) and concrete methods (with implementation). ● Must be inherited by derived classes.

data.question: 38. What is an abstract method?
data.answer: Answer: ● A method declared without implementation in an abstract class. ● Must be implemented by derived classes. ● Uses abstract keyword and has no body.

data.question: 39. What is the key difference between abstract classes and interfaces?
data.answer: Answer: ● Abstract classes can have implementation, fields, constructors. ● Interfaces define contracts only (until C# 8). ● Abstract classes support single inheritance, interfaces support multiple. ● Abstract classes are for 'is-a', interfaces for 'can-do' relationships.

data.question: 40. What is a real-world example of OOP?
data.answer: Answer: ● Car object: ○ Class → Car ○ Objects → Toyota Camry, Honda Civic ○ Properties → Color, Model, Speed ○ Methods → Start(), Stop(), Accelerate() ○ Inheritance → Vehicle ← Car ← ElectricCar

data.question: 41. What are the different types of constructors in C#?
data.answer: Answer: ● Default Constructor - No parameters, provided by compiler if none defined. ● Parameterized Constructor - Takes parameters to initialize objects with specific values. ● Copy Constructor - Creates an object by copying from another object. ● Static Constructor - Initializes static members, called automatically before first instance is created.

data.question: 42. What is a default constructor?
data.answer: Answer: ● A constructor with no parameters. ● If no constructor is defined, compiler provides a default one. ● Initializes fields to their default values (0, null, false, etc.).

data.question: 43. What is a parameterized constructor?
data.answer: Answer: ● A constructor that takes parameters to initialize the object with specific values. ● Allows creating objects with custom initial state. ● Example: public Car(string model, int year) { Model = model; Year = year; }

data.question: 44. What is a copy constructor?
data.answer: Answer: ● A constructor that creates an object by copying data from another object of same class. ● Used to create a deep or shallow copy of an existing object. ● Example: public Car(Car otherCar) { Model = otherCar.Model; Year = otherCar.Year; }

data.question: 45. What is a static constructor?
data.answer: Answer: ● A constructor that initializes static members of a class. ● Called automatically before the first instance is created or any static member is referenced. ● Cannot have access modifiers or parameters. ● Example: static Car() { TotalCars = 0; }

data.question: 46. Can constructors be overloaded?
data.answer: Answer: ● Yes, constructors can be overloaded by having different parameter lists. ● Provides multiple ways to initialize objects. ● Example: Car(), Car(string model), Car(string model, int year)

data.question: 47. Can constructors be private?
data.answer: Answer: ● Yes, private constructors are used in: ○ Singleton pattern to prevent external instantiation ○ Factory methods ○ Static utility classes ● Prevents creating instances of the class from outside.

data.question: 48. What is constructor chaining?
data.answer: Answer: ● Calling one constructor from another constructor in the same class using this() keyword. ● Helps avoid code duplication in constructors. ● Example: public Car() : this("Unknown", 2023) { } public Car(string model, int year) { Model = model; Year = year; }

data.question: 49. What is the order of constructor execution in inheritance?
data.answer: Answer: ● Static constructors (base then derived) ● Base class instance constructor ● Derived class instance constructor ● Example: Vehicle static → Car static → Vehicle instance → Car instance

data.question: 50. Can constructors have return types?
data.answer: Answer: ● No, constructors cannot have return types, not even void. ● They implicitly return the created object instance. ● Having a return type makes it a regular method, not a constructor.

data.question: 51. Can abstract classes have constructors?
data.answer: Answer: ● Yes, abstract classes can have constructors. ● Used to initialize fields and set up base class state. ● Called when derived class is instantiated. ● Cannot be used to create abstract class instances directly.

data.question: 52. Can interfaces have constructors?
data.answer: Answer: ● No, interfaces cannot have constructors. ● Interfaces define behavior contracts, not initialization logic. ● Implementing classes provide their own constructors.

data.question: 53. What happens if no constructor is defined in a class?
data.answer: Answer: ● The compiler automatically provides a default parameterless constructor. ● This default constructor initializes all fields to their default values. ● If any constructor is defined, default constructor is not provided unless explicitly defined.

data.question: 54. Can constructors be virtual or abstract?
data.answer: Answer: ● No, constructors cannot be virtual or abstract. ● Virtual/abstract implies polymorphism, but constructors are called during object creation before polymorphism applies. ● Abstract classes can have abstract methods but not abstract constructors.

data.question: 55. What is the difference between constructor and method?
data.answer:
Answer: 
Feature        Constructor          Method
Purpose        Initialize object    Perform operations
Name           Same as class        Any valid name
Return Type    None                 Required
Calling        Automatic on new     Explicit call
Inheritance    Not inherited        Can be inherited

data.question: 56. Can constructors throw exceptions?
data.answer: Answer: ● Yes, constructors can throw exceptions if initialization fails. ● If constructor throws exception, object creation fails and memory is reclaimed. ● Caller should handle exceptions when creating objects.

data.question: 57. What is the IDisposable pattern and how does it relate to constructors?
data.answer: Answer: ● IDisposable provides deterministic cleanup of resources. ● Dispose() method is called explicitly to release resources. ● Used with using statement for automatic disposal. ● Constructor acquires resources, Dispose() releases them.

data.question: 58. Can structs have constructors?
data.answer: Answer: ● Yes, structs can have constructors but must initialize all fields. ● Cannot have parameterless constructor (except in C# 10+). ● Always called when struct is created, even with default keyword.

data.question: 59. What is the 'readonly' modifier in constructor context?
data.answer: Answer: ● readonly fields can only be assigned in constructor or field initializer. ● Ensures field value doesn't change after object construction. ● Provides immutability for object state. ● Example: public readonly string Model;

data.question: 60. What are object initializers and how do they differ from constructors?
data.answer: Answer: ● Object initializers set properties after constructor call using { } syntax. ● Constructor sets initial state, initializers modify it immediately after. ● Example: var car = new Car() { Model = "Toyota", Year = 2023 }; ● More flexible than having multiple constructor overloads.

data.question: 61. What is the 'this' keyword in constructors?
data.answer: Answer: ● Refers to the current object instance. ● Used to: ○ Differentiate between parameters and fields with same name ○ Call other constructors in the same class (constructor chaining) ○ Pass current object as parameter ● Example: public Car(string model) { this.model = model; }

data.question: 62. How do constructors work with inheritance and polymorphism?
data.answer: Answer: ● Constructors are not inherited or polymorphic. ● Each class defines its own constructors. ● Derived constructors must call base constructor explicitly or implicitly. ● Polymorphism applies after object construction is complete.
